hypothesis_content.title: Negative News Amplification in Low-Liquidity Windows
hypothesis_content.statement: Negative macro or crypto-specific news released during Asian trading hours (00:00-08:00 UTC) triggers an initial sell-off that is amplified by 30-50% more than the same news released during US/European hours, due to lower spot liquidity and reduced algorithmic buying support.
hypothesis_content.rationale: Asian hours typically have thinner order books and less institutional algorithmic buying (e.g., from US-based quant funds/market makers). Negative news triggers stop-loss cascades and long liquidations that meet less buy-side absorption, leading to exaggerated downside moves. The negative funding rate confirms leveraged long pain.
entry_conditions: Significant negative news headline (e.g., regulatory, exchange hack, large fund liquidation) is timestamped between 00:00-08:00 UTC
BTC drops > 2% within 60 minutes of headline
BTC perpetual funding rate turns negative within that hour
Cumulative volume delta (CVD) on major spot exchanges turns sharply negative

exit_conditions.take_profit: Price decline reaches 1.5x the magnitude of the initial 60-minute drop (e.g., initial -3% -> TP at -7.5% from pre-news level)
exit_conditions.stop_loss: Price reclaims the high of the 60-minute period following the news

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: The median amplification factor (final move / initial move) for Asian-hour negative news is ≤ 1.2x, or is not statistically greater than the amplification factor for news in other sessions.
